Budhanilkantha Temple, located in Budhanilkantha, Nepal, (Nepali: बुढानीलकंठ मन्दिर) (literal: "Old Blue Throat") is a Hindu open air temple dedicated to Lord Vishnu. Budhanilkantha Temple is located at the base of the Shivapuri Hill and can be identified by a large reclining statue of Lord Vishnu. The temple's main statue of Budhanilkantha is considered the largest stone carving in Nepal.According to one story, a farmer and his wife once struck a figure while plowing the field, which caused it to start soaking blood into the ground. This turned out to be the figure of lost deity of Budhanilkantha, which was recovered and placed in its present position.A legend states that King Pratap Malla (1641–1674) had a prophetic vision. This vision resulted in him believing that kings of Nepal would die if they visited the Budhanilkantha Temple. Nepali monarchs after King Pratap Malla have never visited the Temple in fear of the prophecy.Budhanilkantha is one attraction of Kathmandu valley as it carries different history of Nepal

Sacred Place to visit. Budhanilkantha literally means “old blue-throat’, carved from a single block of black basalt rock is 5 meters in length and it lies in a reclining position inside a recessed tank of water. Vishnu’s legs are crossed and the eleven heads of Shesha cradle his head. Vishnu’s four hands hold objects that are symbols of his divine qualities: a chakra, a conch, a lotus flower and the club (gada).

The vibe is happy here. Budhanilkantha or sleeping Vishnu is a temple in northeast Katmandu. The temple compound contains a large reservoir with a Vishnu statue reclining on a bed of cobra coils. When I was here in 1998 the place was packed and the day was dreary; on this visit there was a marriage, a few tourists, and the day was glorious. There were devotees making a puja and a woman worshipper was tossing rice onto the feet of the statue as part of the ceremony. I felt almost invisible as I went around taking photographs of Vishnu, the marriage ceremony, the puja, people, and whatever else interested me. The vibe is happy here.

Vishnu with snakes. At this temple on the outskirts of Kathmandu (a little more than a half-hour drive northeast from the Thamel tourist area) is a big sculpture of Vishnu lying on snakes in water in a shelter (with a fence around and a big cloth cover on top) at the inner area of the temple grounds on which are also a few smaller shrines and a few two-story buildings.There was quite a bit of crowd at the outer area of the grounds at the time of my visit maybe due to some ceremony going on because I saw this big "kind of" human-shaped round thing (with like a head & a body but with no arms & legs) wrapped in black and also a wedding display of sorts nearby featuring a young couple sitting on a small platform in like a tent with a painting of Mount Everest behind them and flower pots in front of them along the edge of the tent.Despite a far distance from the heart of the city (the area of Thamel & Durbar Square), I would say this place is worthwhile for its "creative" display of Lord Vishnu; and I don't know if there's a similar statue of Vishnu elsewhere, but there's a Buddha wrapped around by a snake and sitting on water that you can see at Bodhgaya in India! :)I did a combo tour with a car & a driver arranged at my hotel in Thamel, costing 3,000 Nepalese rupees (about US$30), with the first stop being Bodhnath Stupa (about half an hour to the east) followed by this temple (another half an hour to the north from Bodhnath) and then Swayambhunath Stupa on a hilltop (about 45 minutes from this temple) before finally returning back to Thamel; and that's probably the best way to go about to see these sights given the significant distances to this temple and Bodhnath from Thamel (especially to this temple being so far that even the mountains surrounding the Kathmandu Valley on that side are seen quite "closer" when you're here compared to seeing them from the city!). Actually, you could also consider doing just Bodhnath and this temple with a car tour and doing Swayambhunath on your own since that one's in a walking distance from Thamel (about a half-hour walk west), saving like a thousand rupees.

Off the usual tourist trail, and well worth the effort. Budhanilkantha is a very sacred site to Hindus, but it’s also a special experience for travellers like us – being well off the main tourist circuit, most visitors are local devotees…although we did meet some visiting Indians who were very eager to practise their English and excited to have a photo taken with the blonde woman! But the big attraction at this particular temple for followers is the sleeping Vishnu as creator, appearing to float in a pool of water that is representative of the cosmic sea.On the morning of our visit, the devotees were more than a tad distracted by a film crew in action, and the gorgeous green and gold sari-clad film star, posing with appropriate hair tosses for the camera – much more glamorous than the middle-aged Aussie woman with her wash-and-wear travel pants and shirt and sturdy Merrell shoes.While the 7th century Vishnu carved from one gigantic piece of black stone (uncovered by a farmer and hauled to its current location) was impressive, the real delight for us came from the children running around with their friends, pausing on occasion to cheekily pose for John’s camera, maybe practising for when they ‘make it’ on the big screen.

Buddhanilkantha is a an impressive carved stone statue of the sleeping Vishnu in a tank of water surrounded by a few small temples and shrines.I visited in June 2015, shortly after the earthquake so travellers were thin on the ground in Kathmandu and there were no others at Buddhanilkantha. It's not such a popular attraction for travellers so it makes a change from the other busier places.The statue is best seen from within the gates where you maybe able to walk all the way around it - sometimes though you can only see Vishnu from the 'feet end'. However, strictly speaking, access is limited to Hindus (the temple boys will remind you of this) so you may only be able to see it from outside the railings.Regardless, it's worth the short trip to such an ancient and peaceful statue that is very important to Hindus. There is no fee but donations are welcome.It's in the north of the valley and easy to get to from Thamel by taxi or bus for the more adventurous. It's right on the edge of the valley and it's only a few minutes walk to open country, an hour or so to Nagi Gompa (a large Buddhist nunnery) or a full day to Shivapuri Peak and back - the second highest peak on the valley rim.

Sleeping goddess Vishnu. Budhanilkantha is situated below Shivapuri hill at the northern end of the Valley. It is about 9 km from the city center. The hub of the temple complex is a pond in which lies a 5 meter (17 feet) long great stone figure of Hindu god Bishnu reclining on the coils of a cosmic serpent. The figure has been estimated to have been found buried in the ground in its original state more than thousand years ago. It is also known as Bhuijasi. Hindus throng to this sacred pilgrimage almost everyday to perform puja but a great number of worshippers can be seen in various festivals, especially on Haribodhini Ekadashi that falls between October/November, the day believed that the sleeping Lord Bishnu wakes up.

"Om Namo Narayayana". The reclining "Narayana Vishnu" statue, with the stories of it's origin, going back to more than 5000 years; situated 9.6 km away from Thamel, and takes only 22 minutes to reach there.The Significance of this statue is the crossed legs which is resemble to Lord Krishna, who was apparently invited by the counterpart King of this region.The 5 m long statue is at the middle of a pond filled with water. Out court of the main premises there are some shrines dedicated to different Hindu Gods. At the base of the Sivapuri hills is a remarkable statue of Lord Vishnu"Budhanilkantha".. At the base of the Sivapuri hills is a remarkable statue of Lord Vishnu, reclining on a bed of coiled snakes. The statue said to be sculpted from a single block stone, is set in the middle of a small pond and appears to be floating in the water. The stone image is said to be one of three statues sculpted during the Lichhavi period and called Budhanilkantha named after the huge image of Lord Vishnu. The five meter long statue called Bhuijassi by the local Newaris of the Liccchivi – age settlement at the base of Shivapuri hills is also known as Budhanilkanta. The village, now also known as Budhanilkantha.During auspicious days like the eleventh day of the lunar month the priests bathe, clean, perfume, fan the deity and decorate it with ornaments. They also keep a piece of cloth on his forehead to save the deity from the stark sunlight that comes over his face.

Buddha Nilakantha "Vishnu":It is marvelous piece of sculpture made out of Salagram stone found only in the river Gandaki. Budhanilkantha literally means “old blue-throat.” Ananta has 11-hooded heads. It is believed that the deity was carved in the 7th or 8th century during the Licchavi period. Hindus can walk down the steps and touch His feet.The main festival of the year is when Lord Vishnu, who sleeps on the cosmic ocean during Caturmasya period wakes up on the Haribondhini Ekadashi day in late October or early November.Many thousands of people come on this day. Three other images of Lord Vishnu were carved at the same time. One is here at Budhanilkantha and is considered the most important and original, one is at Balaju Gardens, and one is at the old Royal Palace in Kathmandu, but can not be viewed by tourist. The king of Nepal is not allowed to see the deity at Budhanilkantha, but he can see the other two deities.The deity of Budhanilkantha was lost for a while and was later rediscovered by a farmer. It is believed that the farmers struck the buried deity with his plough and that blood came out from the ground.The morning puja between 9 and 10 am is interesting.

Budhaneelkantha. Situated north of kathmandu, Budhaneelkantha showing Lord Vishnu sleeping on a coiled snake in the middle of the ocean, is one of the finest examples of Nepali art. Built by king Vishnugupta in the seventh century A.D., this is a sacred shrine of the Vashnavites in the valley. The pond, in whose centre the statue is located,symbolizes the ocean.There is an interesting aside. King of Nepal cannot visit Budhaneelkantha as he is considered an incarnation of Vishnu. As such being equal to him or part of him he can not visit him.
